reviewText:
Early Access Review

DISCLAIMER: The low hours reflected by Steam do not include the countless hours I played before the game was on Steam. I was an alpha tester for Wilnyl (the lead developer) through his TeamSpeak server and participated in a few competitive tournaments (check out reddit.com/MLAB)

UPDATED REVIEW AS OF 11/10/15

Air Brawl is a great game. It has extremely tight controls, top notch game feel, and a cohesive atmosphere. This game is NOT a flying sim. The planes don't control realistically at all, HOWEVER, that's not a bad thing. They feel amazing, and there's nothing quite like a plane chase in Air Brawl ending with you on top, either by outmaneuvering your opponent and making them crash or being able to take them down using one of many, many weapons and special attacks.

Class variety is pretty good, though it's disappointing that three classes have the same special attack (boost) and one is hardly usable (gravity bomb). It almost feels like the Elder is a copy/paste of the Witch Doctor with a few changes.

That being said, each class is unique enough to stand on its own and its hard to see which one is clearly the best. In the hands of someone with great aim, the sniper/DMR combo is devastating and has insanely fast time to kill. However, for someone who's a great flyer, luring people into tunnels and then gassing them up with poison gas as the Witch Doctor feels amazing.

The reason it's hard to pinpoint which class is the best is because that changes depending on the map. For instance, Neon has a lot of long corridors where you can see down a large stretch of the map. Sniper is great here because of its unique zoom mechanic. But on Sand, a map largely based around tricky, tight tunnels, the Witch Doctor is fantastic at maneuvering.

There are many game modes, but I wish that people played them more. In the game's Alpha and original Early Access release, CTF was the only game mode. It's still my favorite to this day because it gives each player a role and lets each player settle into what they're good at, whether it be combat, flight, or even distraction. Since the game has come out of Early Access, however, I've only been able to find Race or FFA servers. Disappointing, but that's not the game's fault.

Let's talk about performance. The game ran perfectly (100+ fps) on my old GTX 580/i7-930/6GB RAM. I've since upgraded to an r9 290 and I can still say the same. I've had some stuttering on Race maps but only for about a second each time. Hopefully this is fixed in the future. Keep in mind I've been playing on absolute Ultra the entire time, so your results may vary. This game will likely run well on anything post-2008 that has a dedicated GPU (so sorry integrated graphics).

All in all, this game is one that you have to play to understand. It thrives off of feel and adrenaline. It takes about an hour to get 100% used to the controls. You will die A LOT. But once you get your first few kills, you'll be hooked.

reviewText:
UPDATE 2/23: DEVELOPMENT IS CONSIDERED FINISHED, BELOW REVIEW STANDS AS ISSUED
Dev response has dwindled with the imminent release of their other project, Super Ultra Monster Truck Madness Road Brawl, and a winding down of development has been strongly implied here: https://www.reddit.com/r/AirBrawl/comments/470c6l/an_open_letter_to_wilhelm_regarding_playerbase/d0adwc6

This game comes highly recommended for groups of friends and folks of the same skill levels. Casuals beware!

---EXCELLENT PLATFORM, UNPOLISHED GAME---

I've flown hundreds of games and played for a little over 100 hours in Air Brawl at the time of this writing, and while fundamentally, I can recommend this as an excellent party game and at its most basic, it is a very enjoyable arcade flight sim, I can not give it a complete recommendation as of 1/14/2016 and again on 2/6/2016 (v1.02). I've owned this and played on and off since its Early Access launch on Steam, and while there has been marked improvement in the 7 months since, it is not enough to make the core experience enjoyable for newbies or veterans beyond the occasional match.

Vets who sink time into the game become insanely good pilots, and can end a match full of newbies and casual players in less than a few minutes, which drives player counts down until the game goes on sale again. Classes and weapons are unbalanced (heavily favoring weapons with high damage/physical output), many assets are too minimalistic to be useful in flight, and the 'Obstacle Course' mode has serious lag and difficulty problems. Ping spikes can cause friendly fire incidents and suicides. Games are simply too short, and there is no griefing protection in CTF matches. Offline mode is present, but the bots appear to be on a waypointing system and have a 360-degree fielf of view, and impossibly small turn radii, which is immensely frustrating and cannot be learned on as a new player.

Several weapons and combinations of weapons are able to slam pilots into walls (causing very, very high damage), and makes for very small kill times (seconds or less, as there is no spawn protection) and frustrations for any victim, new or old. This is my (and many other players') primary complaint that has not been addressed, nor, to my knowledge, is there any plan to. Sunray mines, shotguns, flak cannons, sticky bombs, and the ragnarok deal ludicrous amounts of damage or physics changes (or both!), and are the de facto overpowered weapons in the game.

This game feels as if it were rushed out of Early Access far too early -- there is  a lot of polish and content creation yet to be done. The developers are somewhat active on their subreddit for the game, but appear to have moved on to other projects (Highway Fight Squad, for instance). A time-to-kill and crowd control rebalance patch was debated, then committed to, and then vanished around early November of 2015.

Air Brawl is not a /bad/ game by any stretch of the imagination, but it's...frustrating, and for a lot of wrong (and a few right!) reasons. Games shouldn't be frustrating. I would be happy to reconsider this review, should support for the game resume, especially with a rebalance patch. However, as it stands I cannot currently recommend this game.

Early Access Review

Let me start off by saying that I've played for quite a bit prior to its steam release and that it's already come a long way.
Servers:
Can host your own, or join up in an ongoing public match. Ping is usually pretty good, with only the occasional lag.

Weapons:
Wide range of weapons from a hammer on a plane to a batapult. Yeah that's a catapult that fires bats.
Some will feel overpowered (You'll curse the sniper planes multiple times a match) but you'll always be pleasantly surprised when someone kills you with the poison darts.

Planes:
The styles of planes match the artwork of the game (which is really great).
They may be a bit hard to fly at first, but you'll get used to the controls. That, and these planes can stop on a dime, stall midair, and perform the most insane maneuvers you can think of.
Some are a bit more powerful than others which can be annoying and aggravating.

Maps:
Very diverse set of maps, from a pirate ship to a city of neon lights. If you have a chance to admire the maps while you fly around dodging bats (Yeah, again, BATS – as in the mammal) you’ll see the beautiful design of the tunnels and ravines you can fly into.

Lastly, the community is really nice and helpful. This isn’t a game where you play to rage and get mad at your team – this is a game where you have fun and laugh at every time you try to fly through a building and smash into a fan… Which happens to me a lot…

All in all, I’d give it an 9/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Had this game in alpha, pre-release on steam, and this review is about an hour after steam release. This game was already well worth the money in pre-release, before most of the features you see in this release even existed.

The basic concept is brilliant. It's a dogfighting game based on a tight control set and unique ship and weapon types. The ships respond to the slightest touch of the mouse, requiring skill, but don't spin out or drag like many other air combat games. That means the game is really arcadey. The weapons are completely unique, and I can only recommend you play the game or look at the videos or wiki to find out more. Here's a sample: the hammer (a comic style hammer that comes off the top of your plane and 'boinks' other planes); the sniper (yes, a sniper with a scope on a plane); the gravity bomb (that sucks planes towards it and throws them around); and so on. It plays beautifully and looks great, with a variety of graphics options and a really quick no-nonsense start-up and shut down. The game models are carefully constructed to a specific and appealing art style. The maps are designed with stunts, tricks, and complex fighting in mind. It's a simple formula carefully crafted to create a powerful and laugh-out-loud feeling of fun and joy, with long lasting appeal.

This is the sort of game that you can and will play frequently. It isn't the sort of game that you'll sit down and 'complete': instead you'll find yourself returning to it day after day, like TF2, and having lots of laughs and fun with friends.

There's also five different planes, each with their own special abilities and weapons, so there's plenty of exploring and replaying to be done.

Tl;dr: Seriously great game. You will not be disappointed with buying it. You will not be able to stop playing it!

In short if you're looking for a game like Crimson Skies, look elsewhere the controls are no good, and the game was last updated in November of 2015. If you need to know more, then read on.

No matter what other good Dogfighting game you look at you will find that the planes have weight to them. Crimson Skies had weight in their aircraft, and Rouge Squadron had weight on its ships. No matter what the biggest problem with the game is the bad controls. The lack of weight not only feels wrong, but you also don't get a good sense of where the ground is and where the sky is.

And the fact the developers say the game's finished, and they haven't updated it since November of 2015, is just wrong. The game needs a few refinements here and there. And they could add so much more to it. This is only the base of what could be a good game, and it's not a good game right now.

reviewText:
The good:
+good controls
+smooth gameplay
+good graphics
+great map design
+decent variety of planes

The bad:
-online community is sparse. There are only 3 servers in the server browser, and all of the require a password to enter them. The only way to find a match is to do the Quick Game option, and even then, you might find a match with only 2 or 3 other people.
-Some servers are somewhat laggy, even if they are in your region with decent ping. You WILL experience some bad rubberbanding.
-no way to re-map keys.

Air Brawl is a very fun game, but it could use a lot more work and boost for the community.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really, really wanted to like this game. I wanted the dev to succeed in making something amazing. It's clear that this is a unique product and has a passionate userbase.

But I just can't get past the terrible controls.

No matter what configuration I use, something about them just doesn't feel right. I've played a fair amound of 6-degree-shooters before, but this is something spectacularly bad.

Okay, a great example: On the options menu, you have X and Y sensitivity options. You would think that setting them at equal levels would lead to equal sensitivity in their respective directions, right?

Wrong!

Because most modern screens are widescreen, the Y axis is MUCH more sensitive than the X axis.  You can try cranking up the X axis sensitivity to max, but it just still feels wrong, even if you try to compensate by lowering Y axis sensitivity.

As for the actual dogfighting, the crux of the game, it's rather boring and suffers from the same problem that Insurgency suffers from: actually spotting enemies is incredibly difficult. And while that makes sense for the modern military setting of Insurgency, for a colorful, fast-paced game, it is irksome.

And if you do spot another plane in the game, you will probably have  a very difficult time trying to tell which team it is on, because despite there being red and blue teams, all the text is tiny, and basically looks gray,  I found myself squniting to read the names instead, and then checking to see which team they were on, on the scoreboard (at which point, they had usually flown away, around some object).

Other than that, I don't think the weapons are as creative or unusual as some would have you believe. Especially if you've played any F2P shooter on the market for the past 10 years.

Don't buy into the hype of the passionate user-base just yet. The game still needs some time to develop and fix these, and other, glaring issues.

reviewText:
I've deleted my previous review to reflect the current state of Airbrawl.

Airbrawl is a fantastic, arcade-esque, skill based dog fighting game; it does what it aims to do extremely well. The fights are exhilerating, adrenaline will be had if you commit to this game; however, you can't really commit to the game much anymore since the community has died down significantly; there are still some active days/times though and you almost certainly will end up adding the people online to play with later because the community still playing are awsome.

If you want to play this game there are a few things you should know. Firstly, the online community is mostly dead; nevertheless, you can still get on during the weekends and find a match occasionally, there is a subreddit where matchmaking happens relatively often (reddit.com/r/airbrawl), and it's not that hard to find a match once you add some people in game. Second, the controls are fantastic, hard, but fantastic; you will absolutely be bad at this game when you start, but don't get discouraged, you will rapidly improve. And lastly the developer no longer supports this game as they have moved on to their newest project.

Bottom line: Would I recommend this game, absolutely! But only if you are willing to suck at the start, make some friends to find matches, or have some friends you want to play with.
